newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks pare losses, but end sharply down.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks pare losses, but end sharply down.

text.p: Mexican stocks recovered from earlier lows at the close of trade on Tuesday on the coattails of a rebound on Wall Street, but were still sharply down on fears of further rises in U.S. interest rates, traders and analysts said.

"The session was very apathetic in volume terms. It was a bear market again and we thought it could get quite ugly, but the recovery by the Dow kept the market in check," a Mexico City floor trader said.
The leading IPC share index ended down 33.72 points, or 0.90 percent, at 3,714.26.
Trading volume was lackluster at 61.5 million shares.
The IPC had reached a low of 3,684.17 points in mid-afternoon trade.
The Dow Jones, meanwhile, closed up 0.42 percent at 6,611.05 points, up from a session low of 6,522.67.
"The volatile Dow Jones is still hauling Mexico along. We thought (the IPC) would hit bottom at 3,650 points, but it stopped short," said Diego Cndamo, head of research at the Ixe brokerage.
"Forecast of additional hikes in U.S. interest rates is weighing the market down and diverting attention from positive domestic factors," Candamo added.
Dealers said the market took no notice of positive manufacturing employment and retail sales figures released in early trade.
U.S. 30-year Treasury bonds were up 6/32 to yield 7.08 percent as the foreign exchange markets were closing in Mexico, after being down 5/32 in early trade to yield 7.12 percent.
U.S. long bond yields were still much higher than this time last week, however, and traders said they expected domestic primary rates to increase later in the day.

Money market traders surveyed by Reuters forecast Banco de Mexico would assign bellwether 27-day Cetes at an average rate of 21.22 percent. This would be a gain of 63 basis points since last week's auction.
On the broad market, 91 stocks changed hands, of which 65 declined and just 13 ended ahead.
Retail chain Sears de Mexico was a prominent gainer, up 1.40 pesos to close at 14.90 pesos.
Traders noted the stock bucked a generally bearish market to notch up sharp gains for the second day in a row. Several traders said they heard rumours of a "sale of assets" by the company.
Sears, Roebuck and Co. owns 75 percent of Sears de Mexico.
Market heavyweight Telmex L shares ended up 14 centavos at 15.36 pesos. The L class accounted for 19 percent of all shares traded during the session.
Telmex ADRs meanwhile closed unchanged at 38-1/2.

Traders noted Telmex L shares had been up for most of the session, while its ADRs had often been down, which they said was due to arbitrage trading triggered by a zigzagging peso-dollar exchange rate.
Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts ended unchanged at 7.9120/7.9140 per dollar, after opening 1.1 centavos weaker.
((--Karina Balderas, Mexico City newsroom +525 728-9562))
